questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with easy fatigability and malaise for 4-5 months. On examination, pallor was seen. Hb was found to be 7.6g/dl. The peripheral smear is shown below. All of the following causes findings as seen in the peripheral smear except:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Fanconi's anaemia The peripheral smear shows microcytic hypochromic anaemia with anisopoikilocytosis. Microcytosis (Reduced average cell size, MCV < 80fl)) . The causes are:- Iron deficiency Sideroblastic anaemia Thalassaemia Lead toxicity AOCD (anaemia of Chronic Disease) (+/-)

Extraedge:

Fanconi anaemia , an autosomal recessive disorder, manifests as congenital developmental anomalies, progressive pancytopenia, and an increased risk of malignancy. It manifests as moderate aplastic anaemia and isolated macrocytic anaemia or thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: Blind loop syndrome occurs when food doesn't follow the normal digestion route and bypasses a section of your intestine. It can be caused by abdominal surgery, diverticulitis, inflammatory bowel disease, peptic ulcer disease, or an infection. Megaloblastic anaemia in blind loop syndrome is due to:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both A and B Megaloblastic anaemia in Blind loop syndrome -bacterial overgrowth causes B12 deficiency. The majority of patients with SIBO(small intestinal bacterial overgrowth) present with bloating [ 20 ]. Other common symptoms include flatulence, abdominal discomfort, or chronic watery diarrhoea. Bacterial overgrowth may also damage the brush border and result in carbohydrate maldigestion and short-chain fatty acid production in the colon, with diarrhoea and gas. These patients are also at risk for B12 deficiency due to bacterial metabolism of B12 resulting in macrocytic anaemia and peripheral neuropathy. In contrast, elevated serum folate levels may also be observed, derived from bacterial synthesis of folate

Extraedge:

Causes of vitamin B12 deficiency Gastric abnormalities Autoantibodies to intrinsic factor or gastric parietal cells (ie, pernicious anemia) Gastrectomy bariatric surgery Gastritis Autoimmune metaplastic atrophic gastritis Small bowel disease Malabsorption syndrome Ileal resection or bypass Inflammatory bowel disease (eg, Crohn disease) Celiac disease Bacterial overgrowth Blind loop Dibothriocephalus latus (fish tapeworm) Pancreatitis Pancreatic insufficiency Diet Breastfed infant of a mother with vitamin B12 deficiency Strict vegan diet Vegetarian diet in pregnancy Agents that block or impair absorption Neomycin Biguanides (eg, metformin) Proton pump inhibitors (eg, omeprazole) Histamine 2 receptor antagonists (eg, cimetidine) Nitrous oxide (N 2 0) gas, used for anaesthesia or recreationally Inherited transcobalamin II deficiency

questions.text: A 34 year old female, with a known case of hypothyroidism on medication presented with easy fatigability, forgetfulness and tingling over bilateral hands and feet for 2 months. Her Hb was 9.7g/dl with MCV 102 fl. TSH is 2.1 mIU/L She consumes a non-vegetarian diet 2-3 times a week. Serum Vit B12 levels are 50pg/ml. What can be the possible cause of anaemia in this case?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Pernicious anaemia This woman is a case of pernicious anaemia which causes megaloblastic anaemia due to a severe lack of intrinsic factors which is needed for the absorption of vit b12 from food sources. Pernicious anaemia:- Pernicious anaemia - Due to lack of Intrinsic factor deficiency(gastric atrophy). Median age of onset 70-80 years. Associated with autoimmune disorders Thyroid disorders, Addison's, type 1 DM, Vitiligo, and hypoparathyroidism . Also associated with -Hypogammaglobulinemia, premature greying, blue eyes, and blood group Africans>asians. Incidence-120 per 100,000 male:female-1:1.6 Risk of Gastric cancer and gastrinomas. Gold standard for diagnosis is gastroscopy with biopsy. Serum testing for autoantibodies towards Intrinsic factor and parietal cells.( Anti-parietal cell antibody-sensitive seen in 90% of patients. Anti IF Antibody is specifically seen in 80% of patients ). In juvenile pernicious anaemia anti parietal antibodies are absent. Cooley's anaemia-Dr Cooley was the first to report Beta Thalassemia(microcytic anaemia) ,hence coined the name Cooley anaemia.

questions.text: An 18 year old female presented with recurrent episodes of bleeding from gums, nose bleeds and heavy menstrual flow for 2-3 months. She also complains of easy fatigability and shortness of breath. CBC showed pancytopenia and Bone marrow showed hypoplastic bone marrow with an increase in the number of fat cells. All are true regarding this condition except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Splenomegaly The history and bone marrow examination showing hypocellular bone marrow Is suggestive of Aplastic anaemia. Patients with aplastic anaemia most commonly present with recurrent infections(due to neutropenia)mucosal haemorrhage Menorrhagia(thrombocytopenia)or fatigue and cardiopulmonary findings associated with progressive anaemia. Lymphadenopathy and splenomegaly are highly atypical of aplastic anaemia.

questions.text: An 8 year old child presents with pancytopenia, short stature, microcephaly,café-au-lait spots and thumb abnormalities as shown in the image. Which is the WRONG statement regarding this condition.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Autosomal Dominant This is a case of Fanconi anaemia(autosomal Recessive) with an image showing thumb abnormalities (“ dangling thumb or “thumb attached by a thread” appearance Fanconi anaemia (FA) is a rare inherited bone marrow failure syndrome (IBMFS) characterized by pancytopenia, predisposition to malignancy, and characteristic physical abnormalities/congenital malformations. Fanconi anaemia (FA) is a genetic disease that affects children and adults. FA is caused by pathogenic variants (ie, mutations) in one of the numerous genes involved with DNA repair. They typically have short stature,café au lait spots and anomalies involving the radius, thumb and genitourinary tract. Prognosis: Many patients eventually develop AML . Older patients are extremely likely to develop head and neck, oesophagal, gastrointestinal, vulvar and anal cancers. FA is caused by an inability to properly repair DNA interstrand crosslinks (ICLs), an especially deleterious type of DNA damage in which opposing strands of DNA are abnormally joined. Disordered repair of ICLs leads to genomic instability, aberrant cell cycle regulation, and cell death. Hematological abnormalities: Symptoms appear progressively and often lead to complete bone marrow (BM) failure. While at birth blood count is usually normal, macrocytosis /non-megaloblastic anaemia, is the first detected abnormality, Within the next 10 years, over 50% of patients presenting haematological abnormalities will have developed pancytopenia. The deficiencies cause an increased risk of haemorrhage and recurrent infections, respectively. Treatment: The first line of therapy is hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. Approximately 50-75% of patients respond to androgens, which are used when transplantation is not an option.

questions.text: A 28 year old female with weakness, fatigue for 1 month now. She is also has pallor on general examinations. Her BP- 120/80 bpm and HR- 121 bpm. Her blood investigation was done- Hb- 7.2 gm%, TLC- 4,500/mm3, retic count-1%, MCV-72 Fl. Her iron profile is – s. iron-75 mg/dl, S. ferritin- 100 ng/ml. TIBC- 382 ug/dl. What will be the clinical diagnosis of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Iron deficiency anaemia In the given question, the patient with symptoms of anaemia like weakness and pallor on examination with lab evidence of microcytic anaemia and iron profile showing increased TIBC decreased ferritin and normal s. iron levels. Hence, the diagnosis will be iron deficiency anaemia.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: B. vit B12 deficiency patient presents with MCV increased and it presents with macrocytic anaemia. Option: C. dimorphic anaemia- there is no such history suggesting dimorphic anaemia, moreover the iron studies are only given. Hence, the better answer will be iron deficiency anaemia. Option: D. folate deficiency- this is not the answer as it presents as macrocytic anaemia and MCV of this patient is decreased.

Extraedge:

questions.text: A 68 year old male patient presented with a passage of blood in stools, weakness and dizziness. He underwent further investigations which revealed colon carcinoma as the diagnosis. His blood investigation revealed moderate anaemia with low MCV and low MCH, most probably due to iron deficiency. Which of the following conditions mentioned in the option will also present with low MCV?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lead poisoning In the given question, as asked the condition which will also present with low MCV as in the given question will be lead poisoning as it inhibits the enzyme in heme synthesis. Hence, it will lead to low MCV.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. B12 deficiency present with high MCV Option: C . Hypothyroidism will also present with high MCV. Option: D . Alcoholic liver disease will also present with high MCV.

Filiform papillae hypertrophy Filiform papillae hypertrophy will not be present in this patient as atrophy is present. In the given clinical scenario, the female patient is a case of iron deficiency anaemia. Hence the symptoms from the given options will include:

questions.text: A 34 year old male patient was brought to OPD by her husband after she felt dizzy for a few days now. She complained of easy fatigability and was having difficulty swallowing food. She underwent an endoscopy which showed the following findings. Her lab profile showed she has iron deficiency anaemia. diagnosis of Plummer Wilson syndrome was made. What will be her iron profile in this condition?

options.label: A
options.text: S. iron increased, S. ferritin decreased, and serum TIBC increased.

options.label: B
options.text: S. iron normal, s. ferritin increased, serum TIBC decreased.

options.label: C
options.text: S. iron decreased, s. ferritin increased, serum TIBC decreased.

options.label: D
options.text: S. iron normal, s. ferritin decreased, s. TIBC increased.

questions.correct_answer: D. S. iron normal, s. ferritin decreased, s. TIBC increased.
questions.explanation:
Solution:

S. iron normal, s. ferritin decreased, s. TIBC increased. In the given clinical scenario, the patient has a complaint of dysphagia to food and the endoscopy image shows an oesophagal web along with iron deficiency anaemia which makes it a case of Plummer Wilson syndrome. For iron deficiency anaemia- s. iron is normal to decreased borderline, s. ferritin will be decreased and s. TIBC will be increased. Hence the correct answer will be option D.

questions.text: A 23 year old male who was very choosy with his food was brought to the hospital after getting dizziness and weakness for a few days now. His lab investigation revealed anaemia with low MCV and decreased S. ferritin and increased S. TIBC. He used to take a mixed diet. He was started on iron supplements for treatment. Which of the following can be taken along with iron to increase its absorption?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Lemon juice In the given question, the patient is given iron supplements for anaemia, lemon juice will increase the absorption as absorption increases in acidic Ph. This is because of the high levels of vitamin C (we told you it was important!), which can improve the body's ability to absorb iron.

Random:

Explanation For Incorrect Options:- Option: A. Wholegrain will have phytates in it and hence will lead to decrease absorption. Option: B. Tea will also decrease absorption. Option: D. Cranberries will contain tannates which will lead to decreased absorption.

questions.text: A 28 year old female was brought to OPD for Weakness and an episode of unconsciousness for which investigations were done and she was diagnosed with severe anaemia. The cause for this was identified to be iron deficiency. Which of the following parameters is first to decrease in patients with iron deficiency.?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

S. ferritin In the given question, the patient with iron deficiency anaemia, the parameter to decrease first will be s. ferritin. Iron deficiency anaemia develops in 3 stages:- Stage of negative iron balance - in this, there is a decrease in iron stores with normal S. iron and RBC morphology. Stage of iron-deficient erythropoiesis - decrease in s. iron level occurs but the morphology of RBC remains normal. Stage of iron deficiency anaemia - fall in haemoglobin with microcytic hypochromic RBC.

Highyeild:

Transferrin saturation is calculated as the serum iron/total iron binding capacity (SI/TIBC). Ferritin is an acute phase reactant, and serum levels are increased by liver disease, inflammation, and malignancy. In these settings, it is not a good reflection of iron stores.
